awd_titl_txt: Signal Integration of the Ethylene and Cytokinin Hormonal Pathways
awd_abstract_narration:
Ethylene and cytokinins are plant hormones that regulate many agronomically important traits, including fruit ripening, grain yield, shoot and root architecture, senescence, disease resistance, and drought resistance. Although these two hormones often antagonize the actions of each other, ethylene generally being considered a hormone that promotes aging of plant tissues while cytokinin promotes greening, these same two hormones sometimes act in a cooperative manner. The goal of this project is to uncover how these two hormones interact in the regulation of plant growth and development. A better understanding of plant hormone signaling will enable optimization of crops to improve their performance in various agricultural settings. The research project will provide excellent training opportunities for graduate students and postdoctoral fellows. In addition, through a local partnership, the project will establish a summer program aimed at developing education and science awareness through participatory activities that integrate science with art.

This research project presents an integrated set of experiments to elucidate mechanisms of transcriptional crosstalk between the ethylene and cytokinin signaling pathways, building toward a systems level understanding of this process. The focus of the research is on the EIN3 and type-B ARR families of transcription factors that regulate the primary transcriptional responses to ethylene and cytokinin, respectively. The first objective is to characterize the role of combinatorial interactions between EIN3 and the type-B ARR transcription factors in the regulation of gene expression, initial results supporting both cooperative and antagonistic interactions. The second objective of this project is to characterize the role that physical interactions between EIN3 and the type-A ARRs, a family of negative regulators whose expression is strongly induced by cytokinin, play in modulating the activity of EIN3 and ethylene signaling. The third objective is to characterize the role that ethylene plays in activating the type-B ARRs independently of their activation by the cytokinin signaling pathway, this serving as an alternative pathway by which to regulate a subset of the ethylene responses. These studies will incorporate global analyses of gene expression and target binding by the transcription factors, using RNA-Seq and ChIP-Seq approaches. Models for interaction derived from these studies will be tested by mechanistic, transcriptomic, and genetic approaches, and placed within the context of the roles of ethylene and cytokinin in seedling growth.

This award was co-funded by the Physiological Mechanisms and Biomechanics Program in the Division of Integrative Organismal Systems and the Cellular Dynamics and Function Cluster in the Division of Molecular and Cellular Biosciences.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
The studies supported by this award focused on signaling by the plant hormones ethylene and cytokinin. Ethylene and cytokinins are plant hormones that regulate many agronomically important traits, including fruit ripening, grain yield, shoot and root architecture, senescence, disease resistance, and drought resistance. Although these two hormones often antagonize the actions of each other, ethylene generally being considered a hormone that promotes aging of plant tissues while cytokinin promotes greening, these same two hormones sometimes act in a cooperative manner. The goals of this project were to gain a better understanding on how these plant hormones function alone and together to regulate plant growth and development.

Results from our studies revealed mechanisms by which signal output from the ethylene receptors is regulated. In particular, we determined that a highly conserved amino acid within the ethylene-binding domain of the receptors plays a critical role in regulating the ethylene affinity of the receptor, and that receptors can be generated with different binding affinities through mutation of this amino-acid residue. We also characterized a family of membrane proteins that negatively regulate ethylene signaling, potentially through direct interaction with the receptors to reduce their ability to respond to ethylene. Results from our studies also revealed mechanisms by which ethylene and cytokinin interact to inhibit growth of dark-grown seedlings, a classical plant growth response that serves as a model system to understand how hormones regulate cell expansion. To this end, we employed kinetic approaches to determine the timing of the hormone growth responses, genomic approaches to identify common and hormone specific changes in gene expression in response to ethylene and cytokinin, and, through these analyses, identified a key role for the plant hormone auxin in facilitating the effects on cell expansion.

Ethylene is not the only gaseous signal found in plants, plant volatile organic compounds performing a variety of roles in nature and often mediating plant interactions with pests and pollinators. As a complement to our studies on ethylene, we took advantage of several blooms of the titan arum, commonly referred to as the corpse flower, to uncover the molecular mechanisms underlying its thermogenesis and volatile production. The titan arum produces the largest unbranched inflorescence in the world and, although its rare blooms last only a few days, they are notable both for their burst of thermogenic activity and for the odor of rotting flesh by which they attract pollinators. Studies on the titan arum can therefor lend insight into the mechanisms underlying thermogenesis as well as the production of sulfur-based volatiles, about which little is known in plants. Our study revealed how mitochondrial bypass steps of the electron transport chain can facilitate thermogenesis. Our study also revealed pathways by which the sulfur-based volatiles dimethyl disulfide and dimethyl trisulfide can be produced and identified putrescine as a previously unrecognized component of the titan arum’s odor.

The completed work resulted in four publications to date, with additional papers in preparation, an online edited compilation of papers on the role of cytokinin as a central regulator of plant growth and development, and a patent application on a means to modify the binding kinetics of ethylene receptors. The infrastructure of research and education was supported through programs aimed at multiple age groups. Hands-on research training included undergraduate students, Ph.D. students, and postdoctoral fellows, who were trained in molecular, genetic, biochemical, and computational techniques. In addition, we partnered with the AVA Art Gallery (Lebanon, NH) for summer offerings of an art and science camp, in which 10- to 13-year-old participants explored the outer and inner worlds of plants through art and experimentation. The PI also participated in public forums to communicate scientific ideas to science-fiction writers and readers, the purpose being to facilitate greater scientific literacy in the writing and reading of fiction.
